subtitle: [Music]
New Thinking Allowed. Conversations on the
leading edge of knowledge
and discovery with parapsychologist Jeffrey
Mishlove.
Hello and welcome. I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Once again I'm going to be interviewing
myself, one of my favorite guests.
You mean me.That's right, I mean
you. This format is quite interesting
because it gives me an
opportunity to experience both the
interviewer and the interviewee
aspects of my own psyche. That's why I'm doing it.
Today we're going to be talking about an unusual
case of reincarnation. It's the
case of Aung Than. Now, it's a case that
takes place
in Burma, in a remote village in Burma, called
Dayai on the island of Bilugyun.
I'm showing you on the map where it is
in a very remote part of the world.
To be honest, I am not familiar with
Burmese names and
the Burmese language at all. So I'm likely
to be mangling or mispronouncing the
names and the titles and the
locations and such. But
it's an important case, I think,
not because it's highly evidential. It's not
considered a highly evidential case of
reincarnation. But it highlights certain important
features of reincarnation cases.
Those features include the use of the
announcing dream that takes place.
I think this is very important because
it ties in the whole
Jungian notion of the collective unconscious
and its relationship to the realm of the
deceased, to the bardo plains
you might say, that the deceased inhabit
in between lifetimes. It also highlights
the very interesting biological
aspects of reincarnation cases where
the death wounds of the previous person
are often reflected in birthmarks and birth
defects of the reincarnated individual. So,
Jeff, why don't you give me a little
background on this case? In November of 1957
Aung Than was born in this remote village in
Burma. Now, prior to his birth his
parents already had
four daughters and they had also been
living in the village for a long time.
They were very close friends
with the village headman named U Ba Kyar.
Now, U Ba Kyar had been killed
about a year and a half or so prior to
the birth of Aung Than, in fact, actually prior to
the pregnancy. Let me get the names correct now.
Hmwe is Aung Than’s father,
U Hmwe. And his mother was Daw Hnin
Own. Now, each of them had dreams in which
the previous personality, their
friend the village headman, U Ba Kyar,
came to them in the dreams after his death
but before the conception of Aung Than.
They had these dreams on the very
same day but they were
not together at the time because Hmwe,
the father of Aung Than had been
traveling, so he was away from home.
His wife had the dream
first apparently. I'll explain why,
because in the dream,
U Ba Kyar, the deceased former headman of the
village and their friend,
came to her and he said, “I'd like to be reborn
in your family.” And she said to him
in the dream, she said, “No, it's not a good
idea because we're poor people and you are an
important person, you were a wealthy person, you
deserve better
than us.” Although they had been close
friends and apparently
at one point when he was alive U Ba Kyar said,
“I'd like to be reborn in your family.”
Well, when the father Himway, U
Himway returned from his travels, his
wife, the mother Da Hinin On
told them about her dream. And he said, “You know,
I had a similar dream at the same time.
In this dream U Ba Kyar came to me and he
said he had spoken to you
and he had asked to be reborn in the
family and you had turned him down. And
in the dream I said, no, it's fine, you can
be reborn in our family.”
Interesting. Isn't that interesting, how
that works? Well, in Burma
it's customary that such dreams occur.
The Burmese
people, who are Buddhist, generally accept
reincarnation as a matter of fact thing.
They don't make much of it, as a matter of fact.
However, when Aung Than was born,
this is about 18 months or so after the
murder of U Ba Kyar,
he started at an early age as soon as he
could talk, age two years old,
to begin to tell people that he was
the incarnation of U Ba Kyar.
It's something the parents had
even forgotten about the dreams at that
time. It's not as
if they had been telling him since
infancy that that's who he was. They
didn't make much of it at all and apparently Burmese people do not.
But Aung Than began
wandering over to the nearby house where U Ba Kyar
had lived. His wife and his daughters
were still there
and he said he liked the house, he
wanted to go inside,
he wanted to see some of the former
clothing. In fact,
apparently, U Ba Kyar’s wife said she would save
an item of clothing for him that he
could wear when he gets older,
because he's a very young child at this
point, three, four,
five, six years old. Ironically,
even though U Ba Kyar's daughters were older
than he was he took a very fatherly
attitude towards them,
as a young child, being very concerned about
their welfare. He also had a lot to say
about U Ba Kyar's life and his
death. And, he was born with some severe
birth defects. I'm going to show you,
for example, here's a picture of his
hands. They're severely deformed.
It's a condition actually resembling
leprosy and it made it very hard
for him to find employment because people...
He couldn't have a job where he
was in front of the public
because he was so deformed, at least that was the
attitude back then. It's interesting, the
reincarnation researchers
helped him to get a job as a night
watchman because it was
very hard for him to find work. But,
in his memories he explained that he had vivid
memories of U Ba Kyar's murder. I'll explain
what happened. You see, U Ba Kyar was what
is known in Burma as the headman of the village.
And he apparently may have even been a
little arrogant
and perhaps a little thoughtless because he
began to develop a conflict with another
villager there, U Po Thi. U Po Thi
was apparently engaged in some illegal activity
and U Ba Kyar called him out on it publicly in front of everybody, said, “You're going
to have to stop it or I'm going to have
you arrested.”
The researchers, Ian Stevenson, published
this case. There's a very lengthy
description of it in
this book, Reincarnation and Biology.
They note that this was a mistake U Ba Kyar made.
You don't threaten somebody publicly
like that unless you plan to arrest them
immediately. Because what happened
is that U Po Thi slipped out of town
and he joined the insurgents. There was
an insurgency going on, this is 1956, and
there were a couple of elements to
the insurgency. There were Communist insurgents.
But in this village, in this remote island town of
Dayai, they were a minority group
known as the Mon. They had their own
special language even.
And so the Mon wanted independence for their
minority. And they were sort of in
alignment kind of with the Communists.
In any case, U Po Thi
left the village and he joined these insurgents.
And then, shortly after he joined the
insurgents, the insurgents
came into the village early one morning
while everyone was asleep
and they kidnapped about 30
individuals. In fact, they were carefully
selected to be the wealthiest individuals
in the village. Apparently the idea was
that they were going to
hold them for ransom and that's exactly
what they did do.
So, some weeks later they sent
a notice to the families. “You want your
family member back, you've got to pay a ransom.”
Of the 30 people they had kidnapped,
including some women, all but three
were ransomed and returned. Three of them
were murdered and U Ba Kyar was one who was
murdered.
Aung Than had
described this murder in great detail. He
explained, as a matter of fact,
that each of his birth defects, including
the tongue —
I'm showing you a picture now — you can't
see it very easily but it's as if he has a cleft
tongue and a cleft lower lip. And he says
that's because
before he was murdered they cut out his
tongue. And it was U Po Thi who
did it, who said to him as he cut out the
tongue, you
talk too much. And he knocked his teeth
out because he had gold
fillings in the teeth, and he says, you
won't be needing these anymore.
And he cut him, his hands, as he held
his hands up in supplication,
he had a sword, please don't kill me, he
cut the fingers off of the hands.
He was standing on
an embankment near a river like a cliff
overlooking the river, he got pushed down
but his foot got caught so he cut the foot.
And then U Ba Kyar fell into the river
and drowned. Of course, he wasn't able
to fight back because of all the wounds
he had suffered at that time, plus he had
been really kept on a starvation diet
while he had been
kidnapped. Now, the researchers actually
went to the village. There was a
reincarnation researcher named
U Win Maung who first learned about this
case in 1972.
In 1977 Ian Stevenson, the great
reincarnation researcher from the
University of Virginia,
former chair of the psychiatry department there,
visited the family in 1977, interviewed witnesses.
U Win Maung went back in 1985. They
interviewed Aung Than
and, I have to tell you, if you read
these reports they are incredibly
scrupulous. They're not
trying to color the evidence to make it
seem like, oh yes, this is reincarnation.
Anytime there is a discrepancy between the
report they got when they interviewed in 1972,
1977, 1985, any discrepancies, even tiny little
discrepancies between the reports of the various
witnesses are all laid out very carefully. Every
statement that Aung Than made concerning his past
life memories was written down, checked
against what other witnesses could say.
If it couldn't be verified, they're very clear,
they couldn't verify it. In this
particular instance, most of the
information was not evidential in the
sense that it either couldn't be verified
or it was information that could be obtained
by normal means. Because, as a matter of fact,
U Ba Kyar's home was not
far from the family of Aung Than
to begin with. But they report a few
interesting things. For example,
they interviewed many of the villagers who
had been hostages, who had been kidnapped
by the insurgents.
The villagers reported that, yes, as
Aung Than had remembered, three of
them had been taken aside and executed,
although they didn't know
who did the executions. They didn't know
how they were done.
And although there was good reason to suggest,
good reason to suggest that it was U Po Tai
who killed U Ba
Kyar because of their public dispute, and because
U Po Thi was among the insurgents,
there's no evidence directly implicating
him in the murder.
I have to say this. There's another
interesting element sociologically going on here
in this kind of a situation. You had an insurgency
going on, you had people murdered, you had
the government offering
amnesty to the insurgents. And eventually
what happened
is that U Po Tai returned to the village.
At the same time, everybody in the
village seemed to know
that Aung Than claimed to be the
newly incarnated, the newly incarnated U ba
Kyar. However, Aung Than's family moved to
Rangoon. Now I think it's called Yangon
Rangoon, the major city
of Burma. It was only after that that
U Po Thi moved back to the village. But
when they interviewed all of
the people who had been kidnapped they
were hesitant to talk.
They were concerned. You know, what's going on, these outsiders are coming in.
It was only because Aung Than's father,
Hmwe, was with him and he spoke the
Hmong language and he assured people that,
you know, nothing bad is going to happen
to you because you talked to these outsiders.
And so they talked about what it was
like for them having been
kidnapped and then ransomed and how U Ba Kyar
had been executed.
So at least several of them were willing
to talk about it because
they had this connection with a member
of their own
ethnic group who vouched for them. Now on
the other hand, U Ba Kyar's wife and daughter
were very hesitant to talk to the
reincarnation researchers.
The truth of the matter is that
they dis-simulated, they claimed that
they didn't know Aung Than,
that they had no idea what this was about at all,
which of course went against the
testimony of Aung Than's own
parents who said, wait a second,
we were great friends. Aung Than as a
young child visited their house all the
time and took a
very fatherly interest in U Ba Kyar's daughters.
So Ian Stevenson inspeculates,
and he's clear it's a speculation at this point,
but it seems reasonable that what was going
on is that the mother and daughter of
the deceased U ba Kyar, who had been the village
headman and one of the wealthy people
in that village, were afraid
that Aung Than’s claim to be the reincarnated U Ba
Kyar meant that he was going to place a
claim on their property,
on whatever wealth had been left to them,
and that's why they were claiming they didn't know
anything about this child
and so on. Well, that is a very
interesting history. But what became
of Aung Than. I know that in many cases of
reincarnation, the young child has the
memories, but by the
age of seven, eight, nine, ten, the memories
begin to fade.
In Aung Than's case the memories
lasted well into his adulthood in 1985
when the researcher,
when Mong, when the researcher Win Maung
visited with Aung Than, he still
remembered everything.
There are some interesting
aspects to this case. For example, he
had a great hostility as a young man
and as even as a boy, as a 12 year old child
for example, he had great hostility to U Po
Thi who he believed had killed U Ba
Kyar. And not only believed it, he had vivid
memories in detail
just how the execution took place and
how that affected his own
birth defects. An interesting
event occurred, it would have been about
1969, he was 12 years old, the family had
already moved away
to Rangoon, but they went back to visit.
He was taken, with his mother, Daw Hnin Own
on a train. And there at the
train station who should they run into
but U Po Thi, who the mother knew.
His mother engages in some
friendly conversation with him. The young boy, Aung Than, 12 years old, is incensed.
He says, “Why are you talking to him? He is a
bad man. He killed me.” He holds up his hands
and shows them to U Po Thi and he says, “You
did this. You cut off my hands.” U Po Thi doesn't
understand what's taking place at this point. He
hadn't been living in the village during
the time when Aung Than, when everyone
in the village knew that Aung Than claimed to be
U Ba Kyar. And so he offers him some money.
Aung Than says, “Money isn't going to bring my
hands back,” and he
refuses the money and he gets really angry. He
tells his mother, “You go get that policeman over there.
You arrest this man. He killed me.”
The mother refused to do that and then
Aung Than goes and grabs some rocks, a
12 year old kid wants to throw
rocks at this man who he believes killed
him in his previous lifetime.
He is restrained. He isn't able to do that.
Well, later on in 1985
when Win Maung, Win Maung the reincarnation
researcher goes back once again to the
village, he's now secured a job
for Aung Than as a night watchman.
Aung Than has
held down that job and he asked him, “Well,
how are you doing? How do you feel?”
And this is very interesting. He remembers, still,
at the age of 28 — which is unusual mostly
as you point out these children do
lose their memories — but he said, “Yes,
I remember what happened but I no longer
feel the need to punish that man.”
And when Maung asked him, “Well, why is that?”
He said, “I guess I've matured.” At this point
Ian Stevenson in the book makes a
comment. He says, “You know,
this reminds me of the definition
of maturity, and that is
to be able to endure suffering without
the desire to inflict suffering
on others.” Well, that's a beautiful case
story. It certainly
exemplifies the potency of dreams,
the relationship between dreams and
the interaction with the deceased.
It exemplifies of course what seems to
be, in terms of the
birthmarks and the emotion and many
behavioral symptoms,
to be a strong case for reincarnation, but
not as strong as many others where
detailed information comes through.
It's also an important case because of
the birth defects and the relationship of those
defects to the memories of the
tragic death of the previous person. Even though
the researchers were never able in this instance
to validate the nature of that death,
how it occurred and whether the
death wounds really occurred as
described by Aung Than. Nevertheless, a
most fascinating case. So thank you for
being with me.
And for those of you watching… For those
of you watching, thank you for being with us.
[Music]
